messageBody:
I certainly was not saddened by the announcement. I use Eclipse (for
"interactive" test runs) and ant (for continuous integration tests,
etc.) and have never used the GUI test runner even once. I don't feel
like I'm missing anything. If people like to have a GUI test runner,
how about making one and putting it in the JUnit add-ons area of
junit.org?


Todd.


________________________________

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Clarke, Andrew
Sent: Monday, August 22, 2005 2:50 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Some questions about JUnit 4


Was I the only person to be saddened by this announcement?
Maybe I'm
just being sentimental here but the Graphical TestRunner's green
bar/red
bar was one of the earliest delights of Junit.

Besides, as a casual user of Java I have yet to find the energy
to learn
an IDE. When I do have to code Java I generally use my normal
text
editor and the graphical test runner, which I find is quicker
and easier
to use than the text version.

I know Kent has an evangelising streak - automated unit testing,
xp/agile, etc - which he has used well in the service of the
software
community but I think insisting on the use of an IDE is a
crusade too
far.

Cheers, APC

-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of
Kent Beck
Sent: 18 August 2005 17:07
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Some questions about JUnit 4

Elliotte,

Thank you for the offer, but we are fairly certain that we do
not want
to include the graphical runners in JUnit 4. I can see that they
might
be useful in a teaching situation, but we are assuming that an
IDE will
always be available or that the textual interface will suffice.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute
